Award.AwardTitle: Functionalization of Metals by Hierarchical Surface Patterning

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research is about understanding and controlling the functional properties (wetting, corrosion, and adhesion) of metals by surface patterning. The approach of this research will be to utilize viscous softening of amorphous metals to impart controlled topography (micro, nano, and hierarchical) for desirable functionality in metal components. The scientific objectives of this research are to 1) decouple the contribution of surface topography and chemistry and 2) to understand the effect of atomic structure (amorphous vs crystalline) on surface properties of metals. For objective 1, effect of systematic variation in topography on properties will be characterized without altering the surface chemistry of a metallic alloy. Objective 2 will involve fabrication of comparable surface topography from a metallic alloy in its amorphous and crystalline state. This will be achieved by crystallizing the patterned amorphous metal without significantly changing the surface pattern. The outcomes of these objectives will quantify the effect of topography, composition, and crystal structure on the functional properties of metallic alloys.


If successful, the benefits of this research will include a new avenue for surface engineering of metals by patterning, which has been historically limited to polymers and semiconductors due to their advanced fabrication techniques. By integrating surface pattering and net-shaping, complex metals parts with desirable properties can be fabricated without additional functionalization steps. The multi-disciplinary research will provide a stimulating learning environment for the undergraduate and graduate students involved. Outreach activities will include demonstration of correlation between surface properties (hydrophobicity and adhesion) and topography (structure of lotus leaf and fibrillar adhesives) to promote K12 students? interest in the field engineering and science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Surface functionalization through patterning has attracted significant attention over the last two decades. Properties such as, controllable wetting, adhesion, reflectance, and drag have been demonstrated by applying micro-, nano-, and hierarchical patterns. The majority of this research has been focused on polymeric materials due to ease in the fabrication of textured surfaces over multiple length scales. In contrast, the effect of surface texture on properties of metals remains poorly understood because of inability to fabricate patterns without altering the chemical and the structural state. To overcome this barrier, metallic glasses (amorphous metals) were used as model materials. Metallic glasses can be patterned by thermoplastic techniques similar to polymers and their structure and compositions remain homogeneous down to nanometer scale.  The work made significant contributions to the advancement of surface engineering of metallic materials. The major outcomes are summarized below:

Intellectual Merit

A sequential thermoplastic embossing technique was devised to combine multiple length scales to fabricate hierarchical metallic glass surfaces. Features ranging from nano- to macro-scale are added sequentially to allow an independent control of size, shape, and periodicity (Figure 1). Previous techniques were limited to a single length scale. Hierarchical patterns are necessary to harness bio-inspired functionalization in metallic materials. The new processing technique is not limited to metallic glasses and can be applied to any thermoplastic material. It can also be integrated with net-shaping to transfer hierarchical patterns on three-dimensional metal parts (Figure 2).

The effects of surface texture on wetting and optical reflectance of metallic glasses were studied.  The results showed that supherhydrophobic metallic surfaces can be created by combining micro- and nano-scale features in an hierarchical architecture (Figure 3). The results from this project reconciled the previous discrepancies regarding the stabilization of Wenzel or Cassie-Baxtor state in wetting of metallic glasses.  Another important outcome of these studies is the surface sensitivity of metallic glasses to processing temperature and chemical exposure. High temperature processing and use of potassium hydroxide (KOH) to etch silicon template result in oxidation of metallic surfaces. This oxidation obscures the effect of surface patterning on wetting. Oxide compositions in different metallic glass forming alloys were identified using x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS).

Diffuse reflectance of patterned metallic glasses in visible spectrum was characterized. Only nano-patterned surfaces exhibited low reflectance. The reflectance decreased with increasing aspect ratio and spacing of nanowires. The experimental results could be mimicked by simulation using coupled-wave analysis. The simulation model can be used to predict a surface topography required for desirable reflectance. The samples with low diffuse reflectance showed large temperature rise due to photothermal effect which can be further explored for energy applications.  

Broader Impacts

The additive patterning technique developed in this project is not limited to metallic glasses and can be applied to any thermoplastic material. Ability to functionalize a metallic glass by topographic control alone provides a new surface engineering tool for metallic materials. The stabilization of hydrophobic state in three dimensional metallic parts has practical implications in making corrosion resistant metal objects.

The project provided training opportunities for two graduate students who learnt metal processing and surface characterization techniques. The students presented their results at three national conferences. The results from this project were also showcased at public outreach events such as, science made simple and national NanoDay. The project resulted in ten journal publications (9 published and 1 submitted). The processing method developed in this project is the foundation of PI’s NSF-CAREER award which uses this fabrication technique for nano-sized samples to understand the size-effects on mechanical deformation.

Summary of Outcomes  of this award

  • Additive patterning technique was developed to fabricate hierarchical metallic surfaces without changing the surface chemistry.
  • Surface chemistry of metallic glasses at different stages during thermoplastic processing was characterized.
  • Metallic glass surfaces with systematic variation in surface texture were fabricated.
  • Effect of surface patterning on wetting, reflectance, and photothermal behavior was characterized.
  • The experimental data were described by theoretical models which can be used as guiding tools for designing the optimal surfaces with desirable tribological and optical response.
